description: Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) allows you to create a scalable, secure, and manageable infrastructure for user and resource management, and you can provide support for directory-enabled applications. In these episodes, you will learn how to deploy and maintain Active Directory in both traditional networks and cloud-based solutions.
name: Working with Active Directory
subtitle: Deploy and maintain Active Directory

episodes.description: Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) allows you to create a scalable, secure, and manageable infrastructure for user and resource management, and you can provide support for directory-enabled applications. In these episodes, you will learn how to deploy and maintain Active Directory in both traditional networks and cloud-based solutions.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.565
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.565 --> 00:00:11.838
Hello, we're here to introduce you to an
exciting new series on Active Directory.

3
00:00:11.838 --> 00:00:15.283
Active Directory is one of the more
important concepts that we can learn about

4
00:00:15.283 --> 00:00:16.292
as IT professionals.

5
00:00:16.292 --> 00:00:19.692
And we wanna make sure that everybody has
a good understanding of the foundations

6
00:00:19.692 --> 00:00:21.690
and the basics in Active Directory.

7
00:00:21.690 --> 00:00:24.510
And we've got Mike Rodrick to
actually help us out here,

8
00:00:24.510 --> 00:00:26.180
to show us what we're
gonna be talking about.

9
00:00:26.180 --> 00:00:28.360
So Mike, what are we gonna be
covering here in Active Directory?

10
00:00:28.360 --> 00:00:30.372
>> Well,
we're gonna cover from A to Z, Ronnie.

11
00:00:30.372 --> 00:00:33.550
This is the place to be if you
wanna learn about Active Directory.

12
00:00:33.550 --> 00:00:38.103
We're gonna start with the very basics
of getting Active Directory installed.

13
00:00:38.103 --> 00:00:41.640
And even just installing Active Directory,
there's different ways I can install it.

14
00:00:41.640 --> 00:00:46.253
If we're gonna install it on a full-blown
server with a GUI interface or

15
00:00:46.253 --> 00:00:48.608
if we're gonna do it on Server Core.

16
00:00:48.608 --> 00:00:51.136
We're gonna take a look at
cloning Domain Controller,

17
00:00:51.136 --> 00:00:54.328
so that we can push domain controllers
out in a rapid pace if we need to.

18
00:00:54.328 --> 00:00:57.563
If we need to deploy additional
domain controllers very quickly,

19
00:00:57.563 --> 00:01:00.170
we are gonna take a look at cloning,
as well.

20
00:01:00.170 --> 00:01:01.980
And then we're gonna break
Active Directory down.

21
00:01:01.980 --> 00:01:05.785
Like I said, we're gonna start at the very
basics, and kind of work our way through.

22
00:01:05.785 --> 00:01:08.790
So we're gonna learn about
what makes Active Directory.

23
00:01:08.790 --> 00:01:12.740
We'll talk about the database,
and the SYSVOL folder structure.

24
00:01:12.740 --> 00:01:17.342
We'll talk about organizing Active
Directory with organizational units.

25
00:01:17.342 --> 00:01:19.820
We're gonna take a look
at user accounts and

26
00:01:19.820 --> 00:01:22.300
computer accounts and
getting those created.

27
00:01:22.300 --> 00:01:26.180
Because really, Active Directory again,
it's as Ronnie said, a very important

28
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:29.780
topic if you're going to be administering
an Active Directory network,

29
00:01:29.780 --> 00:01:33.310
and almost all enterprises
are running Active Directory.

30
00:01:33.310 --> 00:01:37.522
We move out of that work group model
very early on when we're in that SOHO.

31
00:01:37.522 --> 00:01:39.502
We get more than 10, 15 users,

32
00:01:39.502 --> 00:01:43.165
we're probably gonna be
implementing Active Directory.

33
00:01:43.165 --> 00:01:46.375
That's a beautiful thing about Active
Directory, it's very, very scalable.

34
00:01:46.375 --> 00:01:51.037
It can go from ten objects to
tens of thousands of objects, and

35
00:01:51.037 --> 00:01:53.555
even more, it scales very well.

36
00:01:53.555 --> 00:01:57.960
But, that brings challenges as we
start getting geographically dispersed

37
00:01:57.960 --> 00:01:59.073
with our offices.

38
00:01:59.073 --> 00:02:01.063
And we've got offices in different cities.

39
00:02:01.063 --> 00:02:03.945
Now I've gotta worry about
replication with Active Directory,

40
00:02:03.945 --> 00:02:07.720
making sure that we have a consistent
state so we're gonna deal with that.

41
00:02:07.720 --> 00:02:13.798
Replication and sites, and replication
links or site links, you name it.

42
00:02:13.798 --> 00:02:14.959
I'm trying to think of what else, Ronnie.

43
00:02:14.959 --> 00:02:19.530
We're gonna look at the trust relations
that get created in Active Directory.

44
00:02:19.530 --> 00:02:25.315
How to create our own trust if we need to
set up trust with external organizations.

45
00:02:25.315 --> 00:02:27.730
Adding additional domain controllers.

46
00:02:27.730 --> 00:02:31.810
As our forest grows,
maybe we go to a multi-domain environment.

47
00:02:31.810 --> 00:02:33.770
How do we add those child domains?

48
00:02:33.770 --> 00:02:35.970
What if I've got a separate namespace?

49
00:02:35.970 --> 00:02:41.050
We'll throw a little bit of DNS in there
because Active Directory does rely on DNS,

50
00:02:41.050 --> 00:02:44.480
but we're really gonna
focus primarily on DNS.

51
00:02:44.480 --> 00:02:46.664
We'll talk a little bit
about group policy but

52
00:02:46.664 --> 00:02:49.976
then we've got other shows where
we're gonna focus on group policy.

53
00:02:49.976 --> 00:02:53.936
This, again,
is gonna really focus on Active Directory.

54
00:02:53.936 --> 00:02:56.652
We've gotta make sure we're ready for
disasters, right?

55
00:02:56.652 --> 00:02:59.300
We've gotta make sure we're
backing up Active Directory.

56
00:02:59.300 --> 00:03:01.920
How do we restore Active Directory?

57
00:03:01.920 --> 00:03:06.085
What if I've got a deleted object that
changes the restoration process of putting

58
00:03:06.085 --> 00:03:07.062
that object back?

59
00:03:07.062 --> 00:03:09.180
We're gonna show you
how to do that as well.

60
00:03:09.180 --> 00:03:11.170
So if you do anything
with Active Directory,

61
00:03:11.170 --> 00:03:14.240
whether you're the admin
that handles everything.

62
00:03:14.240 --> 00:03:17.840
Or maybe you've been delegated
a task that you're responsible for

63
00:03:17.840 --> 00:03:19.670
resetting user accounts' passwords.

64
00:03:19.670 --> 00:03:23.270
And we're gonna look at that delegation
wizard and see how that's done.

65
00:03:23.270 --> 00:03:26.900
Maybe you're administering Active
Directory but your organization is growing

66
00:03:26.900 --> 00:03:31.260
and you need to delegate portions
of your job out to other people.

67
00:03:31.260 --> 00:03:33.074
How do I do that in a secure fashion?

68
00:03:33.074 --> 00:03:36.979
How do I let the help desk go in and
reset passwords but not for

69
00:03:36.979 --> 00:03:40.340
the admin accounts, or
not create new users.

70
00:03:40.340 --> 00:03:42.362
We're gonna show you how to do that.

71
00:03:42.362 --> 00:03:45.412
Like I said, we'll work a little bit
with those default group policies,

72
00:03:45.412 --> 00:03:47.686
groups are another thing
that we've gotta deal with.

73
00:03:47.686 --> 00:03:51.122
How we create groups within
Active Directory and

74
00:03:51.122 --> 00:03:53.813
assign permissions to those groups.

75
00:03:53.813 --> 00:03:55.310
Pre-staging computer accounts.

76
00:03:55.310 --> 00:03:57.630
I mean, you name it, we're gonna cover it.

77
00:03:57.630 --> 00:04:01.310
So if you need to learn about
Active Directory, whether it's installing

78
00:04:01.310 --> 00:04:05.050
Active Directory or maintaining an
existing Active Directory infrastructure.

79
00:04:05.050 --> 00:04:09.225
If you're new to it, or if you've had some
experience with it and you wanna brush up

80
00:04:09.225 --> 00:04:13.122
on your Flexible Single Master Operation
roles and how to move those around.

81
00:04:13.122 --> 00:04:17.074
And what to do if one of the domain
controllers that's holding one of those

82
00:04:17.074 --> 00:04:17.850
FSMOs fails.

83
00:04:17.850 --> 00:04:19.570
How do I recover from that?

84
00:04:19.570 --> 00:04:20.980
We're gonna show you how.

85
00:04:20.980 --> 00:04:25.480
So, again, if you need to learn about
Active Directory, this is the place to be.

86
00:04:25.480 --> 00:04:27.818
All right, so we've got some
great episodes coming your way.

87
00:04:27.818 --> 00:04:31.057
We're gonna, again, work with
Active Directory from top to bottom.

88
00:04:31.057 --> 00:04:32.019
Hope to see you there.

89
00:04:32.019 --> 00:04:38.959
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike introduce us to Microsoft’s Active Directory Components.  They describe the purpose of Active Directory in a work environment.  Also, they take time to familiarize us with common terminology used with understandingActive Directory.
episodes.title: Active Directory Components

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take an look how Active Directory works with multiple domain controllers and domains.  They talk about the domain and forest functional levels.  Along the same lines they introduce the concepts of trust between domains and forests.
episodes.title: AD Functionality

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike get started with installing Active Directory on a Windows Server 2012 R2 machine.  They discuss some of the prerequisites that need to be in place before starting the installation.  Also they show some of the considerations that must be looked at during the installation process.
episodes.title: Installing Active Directory

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue the installation process by verifying a successful installation from the GUI install.  They also take some time to show the way to remotely install Active Directory and configure a Domain Controller from Server Manager.
episodes.title: Installing Active Directory Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show us how to get Active Directory Domain Controllers running on Server Core.  They show the use of Powershell Scripting to install and configure not only an additional domain controller in the same domain but use the scripting to also create a Domain controller in a child domain.
episodes.title: Installing Active Directory Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show how to get started with a Read-only Domain Controller.  They take a look at the prerequisites to making one.  They prestage the computer account using the Wizard.  They install the ADDS role with the RODC option checked.  They also show now make sure that only the necessary password caching is setup as well.  They briefly mention the benefits of using a RODC.
episodes.title: Read-only Domain Controller

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at virtualizing Microsoft’s Active Directory.  Even though Active Directory replicates between Domain Controllers, there are times where running a virtualized Domain Controller it’s place, according to the guys.  They discuss the problems that exists where there are single points of failure that cause issues and that virtualizing the AD can help.  Another advantage virtualizing AD gives an organization is the ability to clone the DC and deploy multiple DCs quickly and easily.
episodes.title: AD Virtualization

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike dive into the logical organization, delegation and administrative aspects of working with Active Directory.  They emphasize the logical organization units.  Also the guys take a look at creating OUs using the GUI and using Powershell too.  This is the basic unit used to administer Active Directory.
episodes.title: Organizational Units

episodes.description: in this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at creating and administering user accounts in Active Directory.  These accounts are the primary unique objects that we can use to audit and give permissions to resources to in our Active Directory Domain.  So they take some time to show how to create them using the GUI and using Powershell to add in multiple accounts simultaneously.
episodes.title: User Accounts

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie take time to look into the use of computer accounts.  Like Users, computers need accounts in Active Directory to establish a trust relationship between the computer and the AD for administration.  They also show how to create the account using pre-staging as well as joining a computer to the domain.  The guys take a little time to show what occurs when the trust relationship is broken and use PowerShell to repair the trust relationship.
episodes.title: Computer Accounts

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a deep dive in the Active Directory Groups.  They start by describing the use of groups and why we should use them.  Mike shows the creation of groups and some of choices that affect their use in AD.  Then they talk about the nesting strategies when using Groups in Active Directory
episodes.title: Groups

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike talk about the different flexible Single multi-master operations roles exist within an Active Directory Forest and Domains.  The describe what each role does and why It's important to AD operations. The guys even take a look at how to transfer between Domain Controllers and seize roles when necessary.
episodes.title: Operations Masters

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike dive into Active Directory Permissions.   These permissions are similar to NTFS permissions but provide better control over inheritance of permissions.  They emphasize the best practice when using these permissions and show how the delegation wizard works and how to extend the delegation wizard’s options.  As with any permissions in Windows, they guys emphasize best practices need to apply when working with AD permissions.
episodes.title: AD Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss localization of services and controlling replication through AD sites.  They create sites and show how to link them.  They take time to discuss the reasons to use sites and how to create and change them through AD Sites and Services.
episodes.title: AD Sites and Replication

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look into the replication topology within sites and between sites.  Before starting replication, Mike shows how to create a site and then establish the links between sites so that replication can occur.  Then, the guys take a little time to show how DCs are put into sites and how clients use affinity to establish what site they are in.  Also taking a look the protocols used within sites and between sites for replication.
episodes.title: AD Sites and Replication Part 2

episodes.description: in this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue to show more about replication and establish that there are not only inter site and intrusive but also how the AD partitions are replicated as well.  This essentially creates and additional replication topology.  Then, they end up talking about how replication conflicts can happen and the different ways that they do occur between replication partners.
episodes.title: AD Sites and Replication Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at Active Directory Backup.  They discuss why it’s important and when to use it. Replication is not a replacement for backup and can be problematic.  Backups insure that we can have AD in the state we need it. They show how to perform a backup and do both a non-authoritative restore and authoritative restore.
episodes.title: AD Backup and Restore
